ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned more italian skills, like different voices, vocabulary, and other constructions.
Improved my Italian and learned new tenses, pronouns, and other important components of the language. I also had lots of opportunities to practice speaking, listening, reading and writing Italian.
This class focuses more on conversation and actual use of the language than L1 does. It is also heavy with grammar and moves pretty quickly.
I learned a ton of Italian! I feel pretty confident with the language now
I learned Italian grammar, and practiced my oral and listening skills
I learned how to speak Italian very well in many different verb tenses, give presentations, and engage with my classmates.
Developed Italian grammar and vocabulary skills, ability to sustain full conversation with native speaker

Through this course, I feel like I have reached a very base level of fluency/comprehension in Italian. I learned more advanced grammar than in L1 and am now able to basically communicate in Italian and read/understand the language. I am surprised at how much I learned being that language is not my best natural skill. I also learned a bit about Italian culture.
Future tense, four kinds of subjunctive, imperative (formal and informal), conditional, a lot of useful vocabulary and expressions.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I think that the course schedule could be more flexible. Otherwise, it was a very rigorous, well structured course.

Strengths: active class discussions, clear explanations, every class was clear and everything was broken down appropriately, there were several opportunities to practice the skills we learned, received clear feedback and very shortly after exams.
Such a good learning environment, class was always so much fun
I think the course should have more reading comprehension involved.

Strengths:
Sticks to syllabus, very clear outline of material 

Weaknesses: limited group work or fun full class interaction / engagement

The strengths are that this class is a very personal experience - you get to know the community of your language class and your professor very well. I thought it moved at a great pace and had a manageable workload. The weakness is that the tests were incredibly frequent at the beginning of the course and sometimes big assignments were close together/came out of the blue. I also wished we were able to use some English to explain some of the grammar rules in class.

The one weakness was the lack of conversation and speaking practice. This increased as the semester went on, but we still didnt have that many opportunities to practice pronounciation and conversation. I feel like my writing, reading, and listening skills improved greatly but my speaking lagged behind a lot. It would be helpful to go around the room and each person read a sentence or a vocab word or whatever we were working on. Also submitting recordings of our voice for homework could give an opportunity to correct pronounciation and for us to practice speaking but still have an opportunity to prepare rather than bieng on the spot doing conversation practice with a partner who may or may not be engaged.
Otherwise the course was great! I liked the taste of italian cinema and we covered a ton of material. There could have been a little more in class reinforcement of the vocab though.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes definitely! It is a well-organized course to improve your Italian after taking L1.
The Italian department is great, so I recommend.
100% Italian has been the best experience
Yes I think it was a great way to advance my Italian language to be able to hold real conversations
Yes. Italian is a relatively easy language to pick up, easy to speak, the professors are great, and the workload is not too heavy.
Yes! Great progression in Italian learning sequence

Yes, if you are looking for a language to take at Yale, Italian is an awesome option. I was really not looking forward to fulfilling my language requirement as I am not good at languages but I have had a really great experience with Italian. I have learned how to speak it much faster than I did with Spanish in high school and have had particularly positive experiences with the professors - who really care about the students. While I sometimes struggled with material/stressed about exams, the class itself was very fun and the grading was ultimately generous/reflected the effort students put into the course more than solely natural talent (a plus for me).

I would absolutely recommend the Italian program to any students looking at it. I've enjoyed it a great deal, and have learned a lot. The program is also not terribly painful, and while there is often work for every day, it's rarely a struggle to complete, which is not the case in every language.
